are: Fitzgerald Dunning, president; Joseph Leopold, vice-president; T. Reese Marsh, secretary:

be initiated in the near future.

while the open order was good,
yet not quite measuring up to the
other work. At 3 o'clock the engineers were dismissed from the
ranks to construct a bridge. In the
record time of 19 minutes and 30
seconds a spar bridge was constructed and ready for use. In the
meantime, the remainder of the
troops were marched to the stadium, where they worked a problem. In this battle the Reds took
the defense, while the Blues were
attacking. The result was a victory for the Reds, as the Blues
were unable to rout the defenders
from their positions.
The Medical Unit was inspected
at five. Here a marked improvement was noted over last year's
inspection and the unit was in
very good condition.
jaor Garey in commenting on
the showing of the corps expressed
himself thus:
"I was proud of what the
youngsters did as could be. They
acquitted themselves as well on
the field and in the classes. I wish
to express my appreciation to the
unit, the faculty and the student
body at large for their co-operation in preparing for this important inspection."
The inspectors were not able to
commit themselves as to whether
or not the unit would he placed
on tlfe Distinguished List, but the
Military Department believes the
chances to be very favorable.

The University of Engineering
Of all the things that go to make the
successful engineer, none is more important, nor more in step with the spirit of the
profession, than a studious attitude. One
man says about another—"he is always
willing to learn," "he doesn't think he
knows it all"—and he intends to pay a
high compliment when he says it.
The great engineers are always at
school, always learning, always seeking
for more knowledge. They begin with
this desire for fuller understanding, and
they keep it up to the end.
Any engineering operation, over and
above the primary purpose for which it is
carried out, is an active and post-graduate class in engineering, also. So that
Westinghouse,or any other great business,

ACHIEVEMENT

is, of its very nature, a University where
theory and practice combine to make bigger, broader and more practical engineers.
The courses in this University are not
limited to prescribed subjects nor terms—
the subjects are almost infinite, and the
semesters are endless. Men with the
weight of years on their shoulders work
and learn side-by-side with those whose
day has just dawned.
This post-graduate school fits men for
almost anything. Fits them for it, and
makes them continually fitter. Out of
this continuing fitness have grown the
engineering accomplishments on which
this institution has grown. It is, perhaps, one of the great educational institutions of its day.

while the open order was good,
yet not quite measuring up to the
other work. At 3 o'clock the engineers were dismissed from the
ranks to construct a bridge. In the
record time of 19 minutes and 30
seconds a spar bridge was constructed and ready for use. In the
meantime, the remainder of the
troops were marched to the stadium, where they worked a problem. In this battle the Reds took
the defense, while the Blues were
attacking. The result was a victory for the Reds, as the Blues
were unable to rout the defenders
from their positions.
The Medical Unit was inspected
at five. Here a marked improvement was noted over last year's
inspection and the unit was in
very good condition.
jaor Garey in commenting on
the showing of the corps expressed
himself thus:
"I was proud of what the
youngsters did as could be. They
acquitted themselves as well on
the field and in the classes. I wish
to express my appreciation to the
unit, the faculty and the student
body at large for their co-operation in preparing for this important inspection."
The inspectors were not able to
commit themselves as to whether
or not the unit would he placed
on tlfe Distinguished List, but the
Military Department believes the
chances to be very favorable.

The University of Engineering
Of all the things that go to make the
successful engineer, none is more important, nor more in step with the spirit of the
profession, than a studious attitude. One
man says about another—"he is always
willing to learn," "he doesn't think he
knows it all"—and he intends to pay a
high compliment when he says it.
The great engineers are always at
school, always learning, always seeking
for more knowledge. They begin with
this desire for fuller understanding, and
they keep it up to the end.
Any engineering operation, over and
above the primary purpose for which it is
carried out, is an active and post-graduate class in engineering, also. So that
Westinghouse,or any other great business,

ACHIEVEMENT

is, of its very nature, a University where
theory and practice combine to make bigger, broader and more practical engineers.
The courses in this University are not
limited to prescribed subjects nor terms—
the subjects are almost infinite, and the
semesters are endless. Men with the
weight of years on their shoulders work
and learn side-by-side with those whose
day has just dawned.
This post-graduate school fits men for
almost anything. Fits them for it, and
makes them continually fitter. Out of
this continuing fitness have grown the
engineering accomplishments on which
this institution has grown. It is, perhaps, one of the great educational institutions of its day.
